titlestmt.title: The Phoenix to Mrs Butts : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 32KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 169KB to 1.4MB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries August 2023
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of four miscellaneous manuscript poems. Three of these four scraps of Blake’s legacy may have disappeared permanently were it not for the remarkable energy and devotion of the Gilchrists and Rossettis in tracing and publicizing what was left of “William Blake” by the second half of the nineteenth century. Not until a century later, in the 1980s, did the previously unknown “The Phoenix to Mrs Butts” resurface. Amazing things do happen.
Two prose poems, “then She bore Pale desire” and “Woe cried the muse,” in seven pages on four leaves, are likely Blake’s earliest surviving manuscript drafts (c. 1783). “then She bore Pale Desire” seems to begin in mid-course; whatever preceded the first line is missing.
In both style and content they resemble other early works such as “Fair Elenor” in Poetical Sketches (1783), relying heavily on popular late eighteenth century conventions such as the personification of abstractions—“Hate brooding in her Dismal den grew Pregnant & bore Scorn, & Slander” (“Pale Desire,” Object 5, lines 1-3)—alongside a few unmistakable anticipations of Blake’s later poetry, as in “the Nightly Blast that Blights the Infant Bud.” Compare “London,” Songs of Experience: “How the youthful harlots curse / Blasts the new born infants tear” (lines 15-16, Erdman page 27).
Four-beat couplets structure “A fairy leapt.” On the verso is a pencil sketch, The Infant Hercules Throttling the Serpents, though there is no obvious connection between the two. Fairies are not rare in Blake’s work. “So sang a Fairy mocking as he sat on a streak’d Tulip / . . . My Fairy sat upon the table, and dictated EUROPE” (Europe Plate iii, Erdman page 60). They seem to be associated with something like mischievous, potentially disruptive knowledge. Blake’s fairies fall taxonomically between angels and devils, emerging from a dimension somehow separate from the ghost world of history, mostly human, that he readily sketched on command for his young artist friends in his later life (collected as the Visionary Heads).
More carefully crafted, “The Phoenix to Mrs Butts”—the first Mrs. Butts—is designed in a manner reminiscent of Blake’s illuminated books, in this case close to the design of “A Little Girl Lost” from Songs of Innocence (1789) but composed as a kind of letter, and delivered by hand rather than by post. Beyond that, little is known of the circumstances that produced “The Phoenix.” It echoes the lexical imagery, meter (in this case, again, four-beat couplets), subject matter, and graphic design of, say, the Songs of Innocence and of Experience—and, yet again, a fairy:
The Fairy to my bosom flew
Weeping tears of morning dew
I said: Thou foolish whimpring thing
Is not that thy Fairy Ring . . .
Seem a Child & be a Child
And the Phoenix is beguild
All works in the Archive are accessible via the Table of Contents, which is accessible via the "sandwich" button at the right end of the banner. This drops down a second banner that identifies the categories of works in the Archive: Illuminated books, Commercial Book Illustrations, Separate Prints and Prints in Series, Drawings and Paintings, Manuscripts and Typographic Works. To further improve accessibility to the works, we've added a Table of Contents item, "All Works," which twice lists all of the works in the Archive without categorizing them according to genre or medium. One list puts the works in alphabetical order and the other in order of composition date. The latter list would of course be of interest to any Blake scholars mindful of the historical progression of Blake's works.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.compdate:
sometime between c. 1794 and c. 1803
Bentley notes that the date is "problematic," as "The Phoenix" is likely to have been written during Blake's closest association with his chief patron Thomas Butts, somewhere between 1794-1806 (*Blake Books Supplement* page 105). Essick cites similarities between the poem and early illuminated pages, concluding that the work was created c. 1794 (Essick, “William Blake’s ‘The Phoenix’: A Problem in Attribution,” *Philological Quarterly* 67 [1988], page 377). Viscomi dates the poem as c. 1800–1803, the period when Blake moved from London to Felpham and started to write to the Butts’s regularly (Viscomi, “William Blakes’s ‘The Phoenix / to Mrs Butts’ Redux,” *Blake/ An Illustrated Quarterly* 29.1 [summer 1995], page 15).

objinfo.inkcolor: blue Bentley notes that the primary ink in this document is an unusual pale blue with touching up in red, brown, and purple. He further states that the colors have changed as the ink has aged (*Blake Books Supplement* page 105). Upon closer inspection, the blue ink appears to have been executed with a pen, while the various other hues appear to be watercolor applied with a brush.
objinfo.framelines: straight lines at the right and bottom of the page; curling lines at the left.
objinfo.binding: none The manuscript was donated with an accompanying "brownish-Grey mid(?)-nineteenth-century envelope of crude, rough paper" (Bentley, *Blake Books Supplement* page 105).

provenance.name: British Library

desc.objtitle:
The Phoenix to Mrs Butts ,
Object 1 (Bentley, Supplement pages 105-106)

objnote.p: The poem is written within a frame consisting of mostly straight lines at the right and bottom, curling like a vine at the left. To the right of the title is a faint flying figure, comparable to one in *The Book of Thel* Plate 2, with a flying bird to the right of the figure. There seems to be no significance in the colors added to the letters, except that it is often where the blue is faint. The format of the manuscript is similar to pages in Blake's illuminated books (Bentley, *Blake Books Supplement* pages 105-6).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The pictorial image for this plate frames the text. To the right of the title, a human form hovers or flies with arms lifted upwards, outstretched, and bent. The figure faces up and right and may be female, perhaps the fairy mentioned in the poem. Its legs are faintly outlined, covered by a robe or a gown which trails behind the figure. The figure's legs appear to be bent and extend to the left of the figure's upper body, with the right thigh and knee crossed over the left leg, which appears to be streched out and down, though it is obscured by the figure's gown. The human figure appears to be reaching up and towards a golden-colored spot that hangs above it and to the right. The spot may be a celestial body like the sun or a star. A bird, probably the phoenix of the poem, flies to the right of the figure and below the celestial orb. Its outstreached wings and tail are visible. It faces away or to the right, though its beak and head are indistinctly rendered. Directly below the bird, a plant grows vertically along the right side of the plate. The plant may be sapling or a reed with a slim trunk or stem, with a base that is thicker than the trunk, suggesting roots. Horizontal growths protrude outwards from the plant's stem or trunk towards the lines of the text. These are likely leaves or catkins. The plant branches into two main stems to the right of lines 8 and 9. One stem arches delicately towards the human figure and has at least three leaves. The other stem grows upwards and tapers off to the right of the celestial orb. There are several indistinct objects pictured to the left of the plant. These may be decorative flourishes, insects, or vegetation. One object is pictured to the right of lines 5 and 6. The object consists of a small cluster of lines to the left of the stem with one long, wavy projection trailing towards the text of the poem. This object may be a flower with a long stamen or some other vegetative growth. It may also be an animal, perhaps an insect like a caterpillar or worm. Another decorative object appears as an interlinnear design between lines 6 and 7. A dark spot pictured to the right of line 8 may be an insect, perhaps a fly or beetle. Framing the left side of the poem, vegetation, probably a vine with multiple tendrils, grows towards the poem's title. At least two distinct vines are pictured, and intertwine. To the left of line 13, two curving, arching stems branch from one of the vines. At least two leaves grow upwards from one of these stems. A third leaf may grow from the lower stem. The vine terminates above and to the left of line three. The layers of color and small spots, indistinctly rendered, along these vines may be insects or vegetation. To the left of line 4, four spots apear in a horizontal line. These may be insects. Along the bottom of the plate, a horizontal line is faintly depicted. This may represent grass or uneven ground.

component.illusobjdesc: To the right of the title, a human form hovers or flies with arms lifted upwards, outstretched, and bent. The figure faces up and right and may be female, perhaps the fairy mentioned in the poem. Its legs are faintly outlined, covered by a robe or a gown which trails behind the figure. The figure's legs appear to be bent and extend to the left of the figure's upper body, with the right thigh and knee crossed over the left leg, which appears to be streched out and down, though it is obscured by the figure's gown. The human figure appears to be reaching up and towards a golden-colored spot that hangs above it and to the right.
A a golden-colored spot is pictured above and to the right of the human figure. The spot may be a celestial body like the sun or a star.

A bird, probably the phoenix of the poem, flies to the right of the figure and below the celestial orb. Its outstreached wings and tail are visible. It faces away or to the right, though its beak and head are indistinctly rendered.

A plant grows vertically along the right side of the plate. The plant may be sapling or a reed with a slim trunk or stem. Its base is thicker than its stem, suggesting roots. Horizontal growths protrude outwards from the plant's stem or trunk towards the lines of the text. These are likely leaves or catkins. The plant branches into two main stems to the right of lines 8 and 9. One stem arches delicately towards the human figure and has at least three leaves. The other stem grows upwards and tapers off to the right of the celestial orb. An object is pictured to the right of lines 5 and 6 and may be growing from the plant's trunk or stem. The object consists of a small cluster of lines to the left of the stem with one long, wavy projection trailing towards the text of the poem. This object may be a flower with a long stamen or some other vegetative growth.

Framing the left side of the poem, vegetation, probably a vine with multiple tendrils, grows towards the poem's title. At least two distinct vines are pictured, and intertwine. To the left of line 13, two curving, arching stems branch from one of the vines. At least two leaves grow upwards from one of these stems. A third leaf may grow from the lower stem. The vine terminates above and to the left of line three. The layers of color and small spots, indistinctly rendered, along these vines may indeterminate vegetative growth.
Along the bottom of the plate, a horizontal line is faintly depicted. This may represent grass or uneven ground.

Several indistinct objects appear clustered in the vegetation to the right and left of the text which may be insects. One object is pictured to the right of lines 5 and 6. The object consists of a small cluster of lines to the left of the stem with one long, wavy projection trailing towards the text of the poem. This object may be an insect like a caterpillar or worm. Another decorative object appears as an interlinnear design between lines 6 and 7, and may be a caterpillar or worm. A dark spot pictured to the right of line 8 may be an insect, perhaps a fly or beetle. Along the vines to the left of the text, the layers of color and small spots, indistinctly rendered, may be insects. To the left of line 4, four spots apear in a horizontal line. These may be insects.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An indeterminate object appears as an interlinnear design between lines 6 and 7. Above the word "gay", a wiggling line may represent an insect like a worm or caterpillar or may be an extension of the plant pictured to the right of the text.

component.illusobjdesc: An indeterminate object appears as an interlinnear design between lines 6 and 7. Above the word "gay", a wiggling line may represent an insect like a worm or caterpillar or may be an extension of the plant pictured to the right of the text.

lg.l: The Phoenix

to MrsMrs
Butts
I saw a Bird rise from the East
As a Bird rises from its Nest
With sweetest Songs I ever heard

It sang. I am MrsMrs
Butts's Bird Erdman reads "It sang." as "It sang" (517).
And then I saw a Fairy gay
That with this beauteous Bird would play
From a golden cloud she came

She
calld called
the sweet Bird by its name

She
call'd called
it Phoenix! Heavens Dove!

She
call'd called
it all the names of Love
But the Bird flew fast away
Where little Children sport & play

And they
strok'd stroked
it with their hands

All their
cooe's coos
it understands
The Fairy to my bosom flew
Weeping tears of morning dew

I said: Thou foolish
whimpring whimpering
thing
Is not that thy Fairy Ring
Where those Children sport & play
In Fairy fancies light & gay
Seem a Child & be a Child

And the Phoenix is
beguild beguiled

But if thou
seem'st seemest a Fairy thing
Then it flies on glancing wing
William Blake
